BIPS.title: 1. To what degree has your injury had a negative effect on your life?
2. How long do you think your symptoms will continue?
3. How much control do you feel you have over your symptoms?
4. How much do you think your treament will help your symptoms? This includes medication, physical therapy or other treatments:
5. Thinking of all the symptoms that have arisen as a result of your injury, are you experiencing:
6. How severe are the symptoms that you're experiencing as a result of your injury?
7. How concerned are you about your symptoms?
8. How well do you feel you understand your symptoms?
9. How easily do you feel it would be to injure yourself further?
values: I could very easily be injured further

BIPS.title: 10. How much has your injury affected you emotionally? (ie. do they make you angry, scared, upset or depressed?):
Please list in rank-order the three most important factors that you believed caused your illness:

BPI.title: 1. Please rate your pain by selecting the score that best describe your pain at its worst in the past 24 hours:
2. Please rate your pain by selecting the score that best describes your pain at its least (best) in the last 24 hours:
3. Please rate your pain by selecting the score that best describes your pain on average:
4. Please rate your pain by selecting the score that describes how much pain you have right now:
5. Select the result that best describes how, during the past 24 hours, pain has interfered with your life:
D. Normal Work (includes both work outside the home and housework

2. My muscles feel stiff and achy
3. I have anxiety attacks
4. I grind or clench my teeth
5. I have problems with diarrhoea and/or constipation

7. I am sensitive to bright lights

10. I have headaches
11. I feel discomfort in my bladder and/or burning when I urinate
12. I do not sleep well
13. I have difficulty concentrating
14. I have skin problems such as dryness, itchiness or rashes
15. Stress makes my physical symptoms get worse
16. I feel sad or depressed
17. I have low energy
18. I have muscle tension in my neck and shoulders
19. I have pain in my jaw
20. Certain smells, such as perfumes, make me feel dizzy and nauseated
21. I have to urinate frequently
22. My legs feel uncomfortable and restless when I am trying to go to sleep at night
23. I have difficulty remembering things
24. I suffered trauma as a child
25. I have pain in my pelvic area

DN4Q.title: Question 1: Does the pain have one or more of the following characteristics?
Question Is the pain associated with one or more of the following symptoms in the same area?
Question 3: Is the pain located in an area where the physical examination may reveal one or more of the following characteristics?
Question 4: In the painful area, can the pain be caused or increased by:

P4I.title: 1. On average, how bad has your pain been in the morning over the past 2 days?
2. On average, how bad has your pain been in the afternoon over the past 2 days?
3. On average, how bad has your pain been in the evening over the past 2 days?
4. On average, how bad has your pain been with activity over the past 2 days?

PCS.title: 1. I worry all the time about whether the pain will end
2. I feel I can’t go on
3. It’s terrible and I think it’s never going to get any better
4. It’s awful and I feel that it overwhelms me
5. I feel I can’t stand it anymore
6. I become afraid that the pain will get worse
7. I keep thinking of other painful events
8. I anxiously want the pain to go away
9. I can`t seem to keep it out of my mind
10. I keep thinking about how much it hurts
11. I keep thinking about how badly I want the pain to stop
12. There’s nothing I can do to reduce the intensity of the pain
13. I wonder whether something serious may happen

TIDS.title: 1. Difficulty maintaining your concentration
values: Often or All of the time

TIDS.title: 2. Difficulty thinking about anything other than the pain
values: Often or All of the time

TIDS.title: 3. A feeling of being overwhelmed by pain or other symptoms
values: Often or All of the time

TIDS.title: 4. Flashbacks of the accident while you’re awake that feel very real
values: Often or All of the time

TIDS.title: 5. Feeling ‘wound up’, agitated or scared when in a place that reminds you of the accident (e.g. In a car, at work or on a slippery surface)
values: Often or All of the time

TIDS.title: 6. Frustration at your inability to control your pain
values: Often or All of the time

TIDS.title: 7. Loss of motivation to get up and start a new day
values: Often or All of the time

TIDS.title: 8. Pain that lasts an entire day without easing
values: Often or All of the time

TIDS.title: 9. Loss of interest in your appearance
values: Often or All of the time

TIDS.title: 10. Difficulty doing the things that you would normally enjoy
values: Often or All of the time

TIDS.title: 11. Feeling 'numb' or disengaged, as if you were watching the world through a window
values: Often or All of the time

TIDS.title: 12. Anger directed at others
values: Often or All of the time

PSEQ.title: 1. I can enjoy things, despite the pain.
2. I can do most of the household chores (e.g. tidying up, washing dishes, etc.), despite the pain.
3. I can socialize with my friends or family members as often as I used to, despite the pain.
4. I can cope with my pain in most situations.
5. I can do some form of work, despite the pain. (Work includes housework, paid and unpaid work.)
6. I can still do many of the things I enjoy doing, such as hobbies or leisure activity, despite the pain.
7. I can cope with my pain without medication.
8. I can still accomplish most of my goals in life, despite the pain.
I can live a normal lifestyle, despite the pain.
10. I can gradually become more active, despite the pain.

PHQ-9.title: Please answer every question to the best of your ability unless you are requested to skip a question.
1. Little interest or pleasure in doing things
3. Trouble falling or staying asleep, or sleeping too much
4. Feeling tired or having little energy
6. Feeling bad about yourself, or that you are a failure, or have let yourself or your family down
7. Trouble concentrating on things, such as reading the newspaper or watching television
8. Moving or speaking so slowly that other people could have noticed. Or the opposite-being so fidgety or restless that you have been moving around a lot more than usual
9. Thoughts that you would be better off dead, or of hurting yourself in some way

PTSDC-CV.title: Below is a list of problems and complaints that people sometimes have in response to traumatic events like getting injured. Please read each one carefully, and select the number to indicate how much you have been bothered by that problem in the past month.
1. Repeated, disturbing memories, thoughts or images of the event
2. Repeated, disturbing dreams of the event
3. Suddenly activing or feeling as if the event were happening again (as if you were reliving it)
4. Feeling very upset when something reminded you of the event
5. Having physical reactions (e.g. heart pounding, trouble breathing, sweating) when something reminded you of the event
6. Avoiding thinking about or talking about the event or avoiding having feelings related to it
7. Avoiding activities or situations because they reminded you of the event
8. Trouble remembering important part of the event
9. Loss of interest in activities that you used to enjoy
10. Feeling distant or cut off from other people
11. Feeling emotionally numb or being unable to have loving feelings for those close to you
12. Feeling as if your future will somehow be cut short
14. Feeling irritable or having angry outbursts

SLANSS.title: Think about how the pain you have experienced as a result of your accident has felt over the last week. Please select the descriptions that best match your pain. These descriptions may, or may not, match your pain, no matter how severe it feels.
1. In the area where you have pain, do you also have ‘pin and needles’, tingling or prickling sensations?
values: NO: I don’t get the sensation
YES: I do get these sensations

SLANSS.title: 2. Does the painful area change colour (perhaps looks mottled or more red) when the pain is particularly bad?
values: NO: The pain does not affect the colour of my skin
YES: I have noticed that the pain does make my skin different from normal

SLANSS.title: 3. Does your pain make the affected skin abnormally sensitive to touch? Getting unpleasant sensations or pain when lightly stroking the skin might describe this.
values: NO: The pain does not make my skin in that area abnormally sensitive to touch
YES: My skin in that area is particularly sensitive to touch

SLANSS.title: 4. Does your pain come on suddenly and in bursts for no apparent reason when you are completely still? Words like ‘electric shocks’, jumping and bursting might describe this.
values: NO: My pain doesn’t really feel like this
YES: I get these sensations often

SLANSS.title: 5. In the area where you have pain, does your skin feel unusually hot like a burning pain?
values: NO: I don’t have burning pain
YES: I get these sensations often

SLANSS.title: 6. Gently rub the painful area with your index finger and then rub a non-painful area (for example the skin further away from the area, or on the opposite side). How does this rubbing feel in the painful area?
values: The pain area feels no different from the nonpainful area
I feel discomfort, like pins and needles, tingling or burning in the painful area that is different from the non-painful area

SLANSS.title: 7. Gently press on the painful area with your finger then gently press in the same way onto a nonpainful area like you did in the last question. How does this feel in the painful area?
values: The pain area feels no different from the nonpainful area.
I feel numbness or tenderness in the painful area that is different from the non-painful area

HADS.title: Please read each item below and select the reply which comes closest to how you have been feeling in the past week. Don’t take too long over your replies; your immediate reaction to each item will probably be more accurate than a long thought out response.
2. I still enjoy the things I used to enjoy:
3. I get a sort of frightened feeling as if something awful is about to happen:
values: A little, but it doesn’t worry me

HADS.title: 4. I can laugh and see the funny side of things:
values: As much as I always could

HADS.title: 5. Worrying thoughts go through my mind:
values: A great deal of the time
From time to time but not too often

HADS.title: 7. I can sit at ease and feel relaxed.
8. I feel as if I am slowed down:
9. I get a sort of frightened feeling like ‘butterflies’ in my stomach:
10. I have lost interest in my appearance:
values: I don’t take as much care as I should
I may not take quite as much care
I take just as much care as ever

HADS.title: 11. I feel restless as if I have to be on the move:
12. I look forward with enjoyment to things:
values: As much as I ever did
Rather less than I used to
Definitely less than I used to

HADS.title: 13. I get sudden feelings of panic:
14. I can enjoy a good book or radio or TV program:

SRI.title: 1. Meeting your most basic needs (e.g., eating well, good sleep, good personal hygiene, etc…)
Importance
values: Not important to me at all

SRI.title: 2. Being mentally sharp (i.e., your ability to concentrate, remember or think quickly)
Importance
values: Not important to me at all

SRI.title: 3. Being physically fit (eg., strong, energetic or flexible) compared to other people of your age and sex
Importance
values: Not important to me at all

SRI.title: 4. Fulfilling your 'life roles’ (e.g., being a spouse, friend, parent, coworker and/or volunteer)
Importance
values: Not important to me at all

SRI.title: 5. Intimate relationships, whether they be physical relationships or close personal relationships above the level of normal friendship
Importance
values: Not important to me at all

SRI.title: 6. For validation purposes, place a ‘4’ in the Importance column, and a ‘6’ in the Satisfaction column in this row
Importance
values: Not important to me at all

SRI.title: 7. Being independent (e.g., making your own decisions and being in control of your own life)
Importance
values: Not important to me at all

SRI.title: 8. Being spontaneous (doing things without having to plan)
Importance
values: Not important to me at all

SRI.title: 9. Feeling positive emotions (e.g. happiness, joy, self-esteem)
Importance
values: Not important to me at all

SRI.title: 10. Feeling like you’ve got the potential to achieve new or greater things in the future
Importance
values: Not important to me at all

FABQ.title: 1. My pain was caused by physical activity
2. Physical activity makes my pain worse
3. Physical activity might harm my back
4. I should not do physical activities which (might) make my pain worse
5. I cannot do physical activities which (might) make my pain worse
The following statements are about how your normal work affects or would affect your back pain:
6. My pain was caused by my work or by an accident at work
8. I have a claim for compensation for my pain
9. My work is too heavy for me
10. My work makes or would make my pain worse
11. My work might harm my back
12. I should not do my normal work with my present pain
13. I cannot do my normal work with my present pain
14. I cannot do my normal work till my pain is treated
15. I do not think that I will be back to my normal work within 3 months
16. I do not think that I will ever be able to go back to that work

PPDT.title: Enter upper fibres of trapezius score:

ACEQ.title:
1. Did a parent or other adult in the household often or very often… 
 Swear at you, insult you, put you down, or humiliate you? or 
 Act in a way that made you afraid that you might be physically hurt?

2. Did a parent or other adult in the household often or very often… 
 Push, grab, slap, or throw something at you? or Ever hit you so hard that you had marks or were injured?

3. Did an adult or person at least 5 years older than you ever… 
 Touch or fondle you or have you touch their body in a sexual way? or 
 Attempt or actually have oral or anal intercourse with you?

4. Did you often or very often feel that … 
 No one in your family loved you or thought you were important or special? or 
 Your family didn’t look out for each other, feel close to each other, or support each other?

5. Did you often or very often feel that … 
 You didn’t have enough to eat, had to wear dirty clothes, and had no one to protect you? or 
 Your parents were too drunk or high to take care of you or take you to the doctor if you needed it?
6. Was a biological parent ever lost to you through divorced, abandonment, or other reason?

7. Was your mother or stepmother: 
 Often or very often pushed, grabbed, slapped, or had something thrown at her? or 
 Sometimes, often, or very often kicked, bitten, hit with a fist, or hit with something hard? or 
 Ever repeatedly hit over at least a few minutes or threatened with a gun or knife?
8. Did you live with anyone who was a problem drinker or alcoholic or who used street drugs?

9. Was a household member depressed or mentally ill? or 
 Did a household member attempt suicide?
10. Did a household member go to prison?
